what: A package for Blanco Center staff
title: blancocentR
text: package includes resources help achieve cohesive look Blanco Center data visualizations. main use blancocentR conjunction ggplot2, colors can used across tools, included data can useful applications don’t involve data visualizations.

previous_headings: A package for Blanco Center staff
title: blancocentR
text: BlancocentR includes two data objects help working Louisiana’s 64 parishes region designations different state agencies organizations: tibble parishes includes parishes regions, louisiana sf object includes population estimates, geometry, center points parish addition included parishes. can access data via blancocentR::parishes blancocentR::louisiana, can load environment. Let’s load ! can now plot simple map Louisiana outlines parish.  can use ‘fill’ aesthetic designate different regions, e.g., DCFS regions.
code: data(parishes) data(louisiana) library(ggplot2)  p1 <- ggplot(louisiana) + geom_sf() p1 p2 <- ggplot(louisiana) + geom_sf(aes(fill = region_name_DCFS)) p2

previous_headings: A package for Blanco Center staff
title: blancocentR
text: Sometimes ’s useful parish polygons also region polygons. Maybe ’d like map Louisiana’s parishes show region boundaries without using ‘fill’ regions. Maybe ’d like plop region’s name center area. can using get_region_geometry(). Let’s use DCFS regions example! sf object changed 64 observations (one parish) 9 observations (one DCFS region). Let’s plot map!
code: dcfs_regions <- get_region_geometry(louisiana, region_DCFS, region_name_DCFS) p3 <- ggplot(dcfs_regions) +    geom_sf(data = louisiana) + # parish boundaries   geom_sf(lwd = 0.7, fill = NA) + # region boundaries   geom_sf_text(aes(label = region_name_DCFS)) # region names

previous_headings: A package for Blanco Center staff
title: blancocentR
text: BlancocentR includes Blanco Center theme, theme_bc(). theme defines use font families, sizes, colors different aspects plot structure. base text defined using sans serif font (“Quicksand”) size 12 color light_text (“#575E66”). plot structure (e.g., axis lines, ticks, text) use color light_text well, titles (plot title, legend title, axis titles) emphasizes using serif font “Bitter” color dark_text. extra emphasis ULL color branding, plot title uses ull_red (“#a00b0b”). default position legend defined theme top plot horizontal direction can changed needed. can customize theme changing arguments. Let’s create additional example plots use throughout tutorial. Let’s see plot p4 looks add theme:
code: library(scales) p4 <- ggplot(louisiana) +    geom_point(aes(x = estimate, y = region_name_DCFS, color = region_name_DCFS)) +   scale_x_continuous(labels = label_number(scale_cut = cut_short_scale())) +   labs(title = "Louisiana population in 2023",         subtitle = "Parish population by DCFS region",         caption = "Source: U.S. Census, 2023 ACS 5-Year estimates, Table B01003",        y = NULL,         x = NULL) p4 +    theme_bc()

previous_headings: A package for Blanco Center staff > The theme
title: blancocentR
text: like, can add grid lines. p4, can add x grid lines. wouldn’t make much sense add y grid lines, can want using theme_bc(grid_y = TRUE).
code: p4 + labs(title = "Now with grid lines!") +    theme_bc(grid_x = TRUE) +    theme(legend.position = "none") # remove legend

previous_headings: A package for Blanco Center staff > The theme
title: blancocentR
text: maps, recommend taking advantage ‘void’ argument remove axes.
code: p1 +    labs(title = "Louisiana",         subtitle = "A map showing all 64 parishes") +   theme_bc(void = TRUE)

previous_headings: A package for Blanco Center staff
title: blancocentR
text: package includes several color palettes, list named colors, individual colors. Please note accessing colors may different use package experience sourcing colors R scripts.

previous_headings: A package for Blanco Center staff > The colors
title: blancocentR
text: Palettes functions can used directly ggplot code using, e.g. scale_color_manual() scale_fill_manual(), depending mapped aesthetics.  works mapped color aesthetics variable ‘region_name_DCFS’ (can see legend title). region color palette assign colors region name opposed region number default. Let’s take quick look variables dcfs_regions understand difference ‘region_DCFS’ ‘region_name_DCFS’. prefer map color region number instead, ’ll need convert region’s numeric value discrete value (e.g., using factor()) specify use region number rather region name inside dcfs_palette() via ‘region’ argument. step, can also darken color region 9 - Monroe using ‘darken’ argument.
code: p4 +    # scale_color_manual(values = dcfs_palette()) +    theme_bc() +    theme(legend.position = "right") library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union  glimpse(dcfs_regions) #> Rows: 9 #> Columns: 4 #> $ region_DCFS      <dbl> 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9 #> $ region_name_DCFS <chr> "Orleans", "Baton Rouge", "Covington", "Thibodaux", "… #> $ geometry         <GEOMETRY [°]> MULTIPOLYGON (((-89.95041 2..., POLYGON ((-91.17614 3… #> $ center           <POINT [°]> POINT (-89.73721 29.68826), POINT (-91.31832… ggplot(louisiana) +    geom_point(aes(x = estimate, y = region_name_DCFS, color = factor(region_DCFS))) +   scale_x_continuous(labels = label_number(scale_cut = cut_short_scale())) +   # scale_color_manual(values = dcfs_palette(region = "number", darken = 1)) +   labs(title = "Louisiana population in 2023",         subtitle = "Parish population by DCFS region",         caption = "Source: U.S. Census, 2023 ACS 5-Year estimates, Table B01003",        y = NULL,         x = NULL) +    theme_bc() +    theme(legend.position = "right")

what: blancocentR: A helper package for Blanco Center staff — blancocentR-package
title: blancocentR: A helper package for Blanco Center staff — blancocentR-package
text: ggplot2 theme cohesive look across Blanco Center visualizations. Color palettes used Blanco Center visualizations. palettes built using 'monochromeR' package, provides methods blending colors.Louisiana geography (parishes regions) easy mapping. Shapefiles population data U.S. Census aquired via 'tidycensus' package.Includes 'parishes' 'louisiana' data: Louisiana's 64 parishes, region designations via different state agencies organizations, geometry parishes regions, well center points.

title: blancocentR: A helper package for Blanco Center staff — blancocentR-package
text: Maintainer: Claudia Laurenzano claudialaurenzano@gmail.com (ORCID)

what: A ggplot2 theme for Blanco Center visualizations — theme_bc
title: A ggplot2 theme for Blanco Center visualizations — theme_bc
text: theme_bc() adds Blanco Center theme plot created using ggplot(). Customize plot elements like font family color axis colors line sizes. Grid lines x y axes can added, axes can removed, e.g. maps.

title: A ggplot2 theme for Blanco Center visualizations — theme_bc
code: theme_bc(   title_font = "Bitter",   base_font = "Quicksand",   dark_text = "#1A242F",   light_text = "#575E66",   void = FALSE,   grid_x = FALSE,   grid_y = FALSE,   base_size = 12,   base_line_size = base_size/22,   base_rect_size = base_size/22 )

title: A ggplot2 theme for Blanco Center visualizations — theme_bc
text: title_font Font used titles: plot title, axis titles, legend title. base_font Font used text. dark_text Color used axis legend titles. light_text Color used everything else, except plot title. void TRUE FALSE: removes axis elements. Suggested maps. grid_x TRUE FALSE: adds x gridlines. grid_y TRUE FALSE: adds y gridlines. base_size Base text size. base_line_size Base line size. base_rect_size Base rectangle size.

title: A ggplot2 theme for Blanco Center visualizations — theme_bc
text: ggplot2 theme.

title: A ggplot2 theme for Blanco Center visualizations — theme_bc
